text: Montana Goof. Steve Bullock -- late entry into the Democratic Race for the 2020 presidential nomination -- denounced the American dream in a recent interview with Jake Taber from CNN. "You're looking at today, only half the 30-year-olds do better than their parents were 30 years old. When I was raised, it was 90%, "Bullock said in the May 19 interview. Is that right? Basically, yes. The dialogue point is supported by an income study published in 2016 and co-authored by six economists affiliated with the University of California-Berkley, Harvard University and Stanford University. The paper calculated the proportion of children born between 1940 and 1984 who earned more than their parents. The authors stated that their assessment was more complete than previous research because they were working with more detailed data linking parents to their children. Overall, the study found that upward mobility began at 90 per cent for children born in 1940 but fell to about 50 per cent for children born in the 1980s.
